{{about|the Islamic scholar|the politician|Muhammad Shafi (politician)|the Olympic cyclist|Muhammad Shafi (cyclist)|the Olympic sprinter|Muhammad Shafi (athlete)}} {{Infobox Muslim scholar |honorific_prefix = {{small|[[Mufti]]}} |name = Muhammad Shafi
{{small|{{lang|ur|{{Nastaliq|مفتی محمد شفیع}}}}}} |image = Mufti Muhammad Shafi (Usmani).jpg |birth_date = {{circa}} 25 January 1897 |birth_place = [[Deoband]], [[North-Western Provinces]], [[British Raj|British India]] |death_date = {{Death date|1976|10|6|df=yes}} (aged 79) |death_place = [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]] |nationality = [[Pakistani]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy]] |denomination = [[Sunni Islam]] |jurisprudence = [[Hanafi]] |movement = [[Deobandi]] |alma_mater = [[Darul Uloom Deoband]] |Sufi_order = [[Chishti]] ([[Haji Imdadullah Muhajir Makki|Sabiri-Imdadi]]) |disciple_of = [[Ashraf Ali Thanawi]]
[[Mahmud al-Hasan|Mahmud Hasan]] |main_interests = [[Tafsir]] |notable_works = ''[[Ma'ariful Qur'an]]'' |influences = [[Anwar Shah Kashmiri]], [[Mahmud al-Hasan|Mahmud Hasan]], [[Shabbir Ahmad Usmani]], [[Ashraf Ali Thanawi]], Azizur Rahman Usmani, Sayyid Asghar Husain, Izaz Ali Amrohi, Muhammad Ibrahim Balliyawi |influenced = [[Muhammad Taqi Usmani]], [[Muhammad Rafi Usmani]] |office1 = 1st President of [[Darul Uloom Karachi]] |term1 = 1951 – 6 October 1976 |successor1 = [[Muhammad Rafi Usmani]] |office2 = 7th Chief Mufti of [[Darul Uloom Deoband]] |term2 = c. 4 April 1940 – c. 23 March 1943 |predecessor2 = Riyazuddin Bijnori |successor2 = Muhammad Sahul Bhagalpuri |office3 = 4th Chief Mufti of [[Darul Uloom Deoband]] |term3 = c. 13 August 1931 – c. November 1935 |predecessor3 = Kifayatullah Gangohi |successor3 = Muhammad Faruq Ahmad }} {{Deobandi}} '''Muḥammad Shafī‘ ibn Muḥammad Yāsīn ‘Us̱mānī Deobandī''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|محمد شفیع بن محمد ياسین عثمانی دیوبندی}}}}; {{lang-ar|محمد شفيع بن محمد ياسين العثماني الديوبندي}}, ''Muḥammad Shafī‘ ibn Muḥammad Yāsīn al-‘Uthmānī ad-Diyūbandī''; {{circa}} 25 January 1897{{spaced ndash}}6 October 1976),{{#tag:ref|ياسين (Yasin) also spelled یٰسین|group="note"}} often referred to as '''Mufti Muhammad Shafi''', was a [[Pakistani]] [[Sunni]] [[Islamic scholar]] of the [[Deobandi]] school of Islamic thought. A [[Hanafi]] [[faqih|jurist]] and [[mufti]], he was also an authority on [[shari'ah]], [[hadith]], ''[[tafsir]]'' (Qur'anic exegesis), and ''[[tasawwuf]]'' (Sufism). Born in [[Deoband]], [[British India]], he graduated in 1917 from [[Darul Uloom Deoband]], where he later taught hadith and held the post of Chief Mufti. He resigned from the school in 1943 to devote his time to the [[Pakistan Movement]]. After the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] he moved to Pakistan, where he established [[Darul Uloom Karachi]] in 1951. Of his written works, his best-known is ''[[Ma'ariful Qur'an]]'', a ''tafsir'' of the [[Qur'an]]. ==Birth and early childhood== Muhammad Shafi, son of Maulana Muhammad Yasin, was born on 21 Sha'ban 1314 [[anno hegirae|AH]] (c. 25 January 1897) in [[Deoband]], [[British India]] (in present-day [[Saharanpur district]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]]) to an [[Usmani]] family. {{cite web|author=Muhammad Taqi Usmani|title=Shaykh Muhammad Shafi‘: The Mufti of Pakistan|url=http://www.deoband.org/2011/12/history/biographies-of-scholars/shaykh-muhammad-shafi%E2%80%98-the-mufti-of-pakistan/|publisher=Deoband.org|date=4 December 2011|origyear=Originally written March 1964}} Translated by Zameelur Rahman from introduction to {{cite book|title=احكام القرآن / Aḥkām al-Qur’ān|volume=Volume 3|pages=1–19|language=Arabic|publisher=ادارة القرآن والعلوم الاسلامية / Idārat al-Qur’ān wa-al-‘Ulūm al-Islāmīyah|location=Karachi|author1=Zafar Ahmad Usmani|author2=Jamil Ahmad Thanawi|author3=Muhammad Shafi Deobandi|author4=Muhammad Idris Kandhlawi|year=2008|origyear=First published 1987}} {{cite book|title=حیات مفتی اعظم / Ḥayāt-i Muftī-yi A‘ẓam|author=Muhammad Rafi Usmani|date=May 2005|origyear=First published 1994|publisher=ادارة المعارف / Idāratul-Ma‘ārif|location=Karachi|language=Urdu}} He was given the name "Muhammad Shafi" ({{lang|ur|محمد شفيع}}) by his father's ''shaikh'', [[Maulana Rashid Ahmad Gangohi]], though he was originally named "Muhammad Mubin" ({{lang|ur|محمد مبین}}) by his grandfather, Khalifah Tahsin Ali. {{cite book|title=History of the Dar al-Ulum Deoband|volume=Volume 2|year=1981|publisher=Idara-e Ihtemam, Dar al-Ulum|location=Deoband, India|author=Sayyid Mahbub Rizvi|others=Translated by Prof. Murtaz Husain F. Quraishi}} {{cite interview|subject=Muhammad Shafi Deobandi|date=c. 1973|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JA86vFqX8f4}} Shafi grew up in a religious environment. As a child he played in the courtyard of Darul Uloom Deoband and sat in the company of his father, who was a teacher at the school. ==Education== At about the age of five, Shafi began ''nazirah'' (reading of the [[Qur'an]]) with Hafiz Muhammad Azim at the Darul Uloom. After reading the Qur'an, he did ''[[hifz]]'' (memorization of the Qur'an) with Hafiz Abdul Azim and Hafiz Namdar Khan. {{cite book|title=معارف القرآن / Ma‘āriful-Qur’ān|volume=Volume 1|pages=59–71|chapter=تمہید / Tamhīd|trans-chapter=Introduction|author=Muhammad Shafi Deobandi|language=Urdu|publisher=Idāratul-Ma‘ārif|location=Karachi|date=April 2008|origyear=Cited chapter written October 1972}} In 1325 AH (1907/1908) he commenced the study of Urdu, Persian, mathematics and other subjects at Darul Uloom Deoband, which he completed within the next five years under the supervision of his father. He studied arithmetic and Euclid from his uncle Munshi Manzur Ahmad and ''[[tajwid]]'' from Qari Muhammad Yusuf Miruthi. Along with teaching Shafi the Persian books, Maulana Yasin also instructed him in the elementary [[Arabic]] books of ''sarf'' (morphology), ''nahw'' (grammar), and ''[[fiqh]]'' (jurisprudence), up to ''Fusul-i Akbari'', ''Hidayat an-Nahw'', and ''Munyat al-Musalli''. In 1330 AH (1912) or 1331 AH (1913) Shafi was formally enrolled in the upper level Arabic classes of Darul Uloom Deoband. He did Daurah Hadith in 1335 AH (1916/1917) under the supervision of Anwar Shah Kashmiri, and completed his education in 1336 AH (1917/1918). The teachers under whom Shafi formally studied included: *[[Allamah Anwar Shah Kashmiri]] *[[Allamah Shabbir Ahmad Usmani]] *Maulana Mufti Azizur Rahman Usmani *Maulana Sayyid Miyan Asghar Husain Deobandi *Maulana Muhammad Izaz Ali Amrohi *Maulana Muhammad Rasul Khan *Maulana Muhammad Ibrahim Balliyawi *Maulana Ghulam Rasul Hazarwi *Maulana Muhammad Ahmad ibn [[Muhammad Qasim Nanautawi]] Foremost among his teachers was Anwar Shah Kashmiri, who was the school's Sadr Mudarris (head teacher). Some of the books Shafi studied with him were ''[[Sahih al-Bukhari]]'', ''[[Jami' at-Tirmidhi]]'' (with the exception of a small part), [[at-Tirmidhi]]'s ''[[Shama'il Muhammadiyah|Shama'il]]'' and '''Ilal'', ''al-Falsafah al-'Arabiyah'' on modern philosophy, and ''Sharh an-Nafisi'' on medicine (''tibb''). Shafi was among Kashmiri's closest students, and Kashmiri would later select Shafi for assistance in refuting the [[Ahmadiyya Movement]]. Shafi studied ''[[Sahih Muslim]]'' and half of ''[[al-Hidayah (book)|Hidayah]]'' with Shabbir Ahmad Usmani, whom he would later accompany in the movement to create Pakistan. With Maulana Asghar Husain he studied the hadith collections ''[[Sunan Abu Dawud]]'', ''[[Sunan an-Nasa'i]]'', and the remainder of ''Jami' at-Tirmidhi''. With Azizur Rahman, head of the Darul Uloom's [[Fatwa]] Department, Shafi studied the [[Muwatta Imam Malik|Muwatta]] of [[Imam Malik]] in the transmission of [[Yahya al-Laithi|Yahya ibn Yahya]] and the transmission of [[Muhammad al-Shaybani|ash-Shaybani]], [[at-Tahawi]]'s ''Sharh Ma'ani al-Athar'', ''[[Tafsir al-Jalalayn]]'', ''[[Mishkat al-Masabih]]'', [[Ibn Hajar al-Asqalani|Ibn Hajar]]'s ''Sharh Nukhbat al-Fikar'', and ''Hisn-i Hasin''. He studied ''Sunan Ibn Majah'' with Ghulam Rasul Hazarwi. With Izaz Ali he studied all the books of literature, [[Maibazi]]'s ''Sharh Hidayat al-Hikmah'', [[at-Taftazani]]'s ''Sharh al-'Aqa'id al-Nasafiyah'', Ubayd Allah al-Mahbubi's ''Sharh al-Wiqayah'', and some other treatises. With Maulana Muhammad Ibrahim he studied ''[[Mulla Sadra|Sadra]]'' and ''[[Shams al-Bazighah]]''. After Daurah a few books still remained, including ''Qazi'', ''Mir Zahid'', and ''Umur-i 'Ammah''—these were completed in 1336 AH (1917/1918). In that year Shafi was also appointed to teach some lessons. ==Teaching career== Maulana Shafi was formally appointed as a teacher in Darul Uloom Deoband in 1337 AH (1918/1919). He began teaching the elementary level books of the curriculum and eventually reached the level of Daurah Hadith. The first book of Daurah level that he was given was ''[[Muwatta Imam Malik]]'', and he later taught other books. In 1354 AH (1935/1936) he was entrusted with teaching ''[[Sunan Abu Dawud]]'' for some time in place of Maulana Asghar Husain. On Husain's request he was given this lecture permanently, and he taught it until he left Darul Uloom Deoband in 1362 AH (1943). Shafi was regarded as an exceptional lecturer on many subjects, but two of his lessons were most famous—one was ''Sunan Abu Dawud'', and the other was ''Maqamat al-Hariri'' in Arabic literature. After leaving Darul Uloom Deoband, he taught ''[[Sahih al-Bukhari]]'' for three months at [[Jamiah Islamiyah Dabhel]], filling in for [[Maulana Shabbir Ahmad Usmani]]. Shafi established [[Darul Uloom Karachi]] in Shawwal 1370 AH (1951). There he taught ''Sahih al-Bukhari'' for several years, as well as ''Muwatta Malik'' and ''[[Shama'il at-Tirmidhi]]''. Whenever due to health or other responsibilities he was unable to teach the whole of ''Bukhari'', then those years he would teach until the Book of Wudu, and other teachers would cover the remainder. In the last four years of his life, he was bedridden and thus unable to teach regularly. However, on the insistence of students and teachers, every year he taught the first lesson of ''Sahih al-Bukhari'' and the last lessons of the [[Sihah Sittah]]. ==Issuance of fatawa== From the beginning of his teaching career Maulana Shafi frequently assisted Mufti Azizur Rahman, then head of the school's [[fatwa]] department. Azizur Rahman resigned from the Darul Uloom in 1344 AH (1925/1926). Others occupied the post of Sadr Mufti (Chief Mufti) until the Majlis-e-Shura of Darul Uloom Deoband appointed Shafi to the post on 28 Rabi al-Awwal 1350 AH (c. 13 August 1931).{{#tag:ref|Mufti Muhammad Shafi writes in the introduction to ''Ma'ariful Qur'an'' that he occupied the post from 1349 AH.|group="note"}} In additions to undertaking the duties of fatwa-writing, Shafi also continued to teach some books of hadith and tafsir. In Rajab 1351 (November 1932) Shafi published a tract entitled ''Nihayat al-arab fi ghayat an-nasab'' on [[Caste system among Muslims#In South Asia|caste]]. The weavers of the Deoband area (who were regarded as a lower caste) revolted against the fatwa, and from early 1353 AH (1934/1935) to late 1354 AH (1935/1936) rallies were held and threats were made against Shafi, in response to which a group of teachers took to acting as his bodyguards. Several scholars wrote or spoke in defense of the fatwa, including Shafi's shaikh Ashraf Ali Thanawi, Sayyid Asghar Husain, and Husain Ahmad Madani. Due to the controversy, Shafi asked to be transferred to the teaching department, a request that was eventually granted by the Majlis-e-Shura in Sha'ban 1354 AH (c. November 1935).{{cite book|last=Buehler|first=Arthur F.|title=Sayyids and Sharifs in Muslim Societies: The Living Links to the Prophet|editor-last=Morimoto|editor-first=Kazuo|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=9780203123157|page=239|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5VnmEMh0MF4C&pg=PA239|chapter=Trends of ashrāfization in India}} Shafi remained in the teaching department over the next few years, during which two other ulama held the post of Sadr Mufti. On 25 Safar 1359 AH (c. 4 April 1940), Shafi was appointed to the office a second time. He held the post until he left Darul Uloom Deoband in Rabi al-Awwal 1362 AH (March 1943).{{#tag:ref|Rizvi writes that Shafi occupied the post until 1361 AH (1942).|group="note"}} Estimates of the number of fatwas that he issued while at Darul Uloom Deoband range from 26,000 to over 40,000. Some of Muhammad Shafi's fatwas have been published in eight large volumes titled ''Imdad al-Muftin'', while the majority remain unpublished. ==Sufism== From an early age, Shafi frequently attended the gatherings of [[Maulana Mahmud Hasan]]. Then when Mahmud Hasan was [[Malta exiles|imprisoned in Malta]], Shafi consulted [[Maulana Ashraf Ali Thanawi]]. Mahmud Hasan returned to Deoband on 20 Ramadan 1338 AH (June 1920). In 1339 AH (1920) Shafi gave ''bay'at'' (allegiance) at his hand. However, Mahmud Hasan died a few months later on 18 Rabi al-awwal AH (November 1920). Shafi returned to Thanawi after Mahmud Hasan's death. In Rabi ath-thani 1349 AH (1930) he received ''ijazat-i bay'at'' (permission to take disciples) and ''khilafah'' (spiritual successorship). ==Pakistan Movement== At the time Muhammad Shafi was teaching at Darul Uloom Deoband, Indians were struggling for independence from the British. When the [[All-India Muslim League]] was formed to campaign for the creation of a separate Muslim state, [[Ashraf Ali Thanvi]] instructed all ''[[ulama]]'' and Muslims in general to support this campaign. Muhammad Shafi, with other scholars including Zafar Ahmad Usmani, joined the [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam]], a council of Islamic scholars formed by [[Shabbir Ahmad Usmani]] to campaign for the creation of Pakistan. In 1363 AH (1944) Muhammad Shafi resigned from teaching and issuing fatwas at Darul Uloom Deoband in order to devote his time to the movement for the creation of Pakistan. He toured India, gave speeches, and issued ''fatwas'' for this purpose. ==Migration to Pakistan== After [[Pakistan Movement|independence]], in 1367 AH (1948), Muhammad Shafi left his hometown of Deoband and immigrated to Pakistan. He founded [[Darul Uloom Karachi]] in 1370 AH (1950/1951). Muhammad Shafi died on 10 Shawwal 1396 (6 October 1976). ==Works== He wrote around one hundred books [[Exegesis#Islam|explaining]] the [[Quran]] and interpreting [[Sharia|Islamic law]]. His best-known and most widely translated work is the ''[[Ma'ariful Qur'an]]'' ("The Wisdom of the Quran"), which he finished (in Urdu) four years before his death.''Ma'ariful Qur'an: A Comprehensive Commentary on the Holy Qur'an'' (Karachi: Mataba-e-Darul-Ulomm Karachi, 2008 ed.), Volume 1. p. xv This work, a commentary on the entire Quran, began as a series of weekly lectures on [[Radio Pakistan]] that ran for ten years. ==External Links== *[https://archive.org/details/UrduBooksCollection_20170511] *[https://archive.org/details/EnglishBooksCollection] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Pakistan Movement}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Muhammad Shafi Deobandi}} [[Category:Pakistani Islamic religious leaders]] [[Category:Deobandis]] [[Category:Pakistani Sunni Muslim scholars of Islam]] [[Category:Jurisprudence academics]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:Muhajir people]] [[Category:Grand Muftis of Pakistan]]

[[Net neutrality]] is the principle that governments should mandate [[Internet service provider]]s to treat all data on the [[Internet]] the same, and not discriminate or charge differently by user, content, website, platform, application, type of attached equipment, or method of communication.<ref>{{cite report | first=Angele A. | last=Gilroy | title=Access to Broadband Networks: The Net Neutrality Debate | page=1 | publisher=DIANE Publishing | isbn=978-1437984545 | date=March 11, 2011}}</ref> For instance, under these principles, internet service providers are unable to intentionally block, slow down or charge money for specific websites and online content.
==Summary== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ !Country !Status on net neutrality !Year |- |{{flag|Argentina}} |Enforced |2014 |- |{{flag|Australia}} |Not enforced | |- |{{flag|Belgium}} |Enforced | |- |{{flag|Brazil}} |Enforced |2014 |- |{{flag|Canada}} |Enforced | |- |{{flag|Chile}} |Enforced |2010 |- |{{flag|China}} |Not enforced | |- |{{flag|India}} |Enforced |2018 |- |{{flag|Israel}} |Enforced |2014 |- |{{flag|Japan}} |Enforced | |- |{{flag|Mexico}} |Enforced | |- |{{flag|Netherlands}} |Enforced |2012 |- |{{flag|Russia}} |Enforced |2016 |- |{{flag|Slovenia}} |Enforced |2013 |- |{{flag|South Korea}} |Enforced | |- |{{flag|United States}} |Not enforced | |- |{{flag|Uruguay}} |Not enforced | |}
==By country==
=== Argentina === The Law 27,078, of 2014, under the Article 56 establishes the right of users to access, use, send, receive or offer any content, application, service or protocol through the Internet without any restriction, discrimination, distinction or blocking. Article 57 forbids “ICT service providers” from blocking, interfering, or restricting any content, application, service, or protocol; price discrimination by virtue of its contents. Article 57 also establishes an exception allowing blocking or restrictions solely under a judicial order or by the user of the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://servicios.infoleg.gob.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/235000-239999/239771/norma.htm|title=Law 27,078|publisher=InfoLEG}}</ref>
===Belgium=== In Belgium, net neutrality was discussed in the [[Kamer van Volksvertegenwoordigers|parliament]] in June 2011. Three parties ([[Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams|CD&V]], [[Nieuw-Vlaamse Alliantie|N-VA]] & [[Parti Socialiste (België)|PS]]) jointly proposed a text to introduce the concept of net neutrality in the telecom law.<ref>[http://www.dekamer.be/FLWB/PDF/53/1467/53K1467002.pdf proposition 53 1467/002] dekamer.be, 27 August 2011</ref>
===Brazil=== {{main |Brazilian Civil Rights Framework for the Internet}} In 2014, the Brazilian government passed a law which expressly upholds net neutrality, "guaranteeing equal access to the Internet and protecting the privacy of its users in the wake of U.S. spying revelations".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/3/26/brazil-internet-constitution.html|title=Net neutrality wins in Brazil’s ‘Internet Constitution’ - Al Jazeera America|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
The Brazilian Civil Rights Framework for the Internet (in {{lang-pt|Marco Civil da Internet}}, officially Law No 12.965) became law on April 23, 2014 at the [[Global Multistakeholder Meeting on the Future of Internet Governance]]. It governs the use of the [[Internet in Brazil]], through forecasting principles, guarantees, rights and duties to those who use the network as well as the determination of guidelines for state action. The legislation was used as basis to block the popular [[WhatsApp]] application in Brazilian territory, a decision lifted soon afterwards, experts claiming that it was, in actuality, against the Framework, which was misinterpreted by the judiciary.<ref>[http://www.tjsp.jus.br/institucional/canaiscomunicacao/noticias/Noticia.aspx?Id=29056 "São Paulo Court of Justice - Justiça determina bloqueio do aplicativo WhatsApp"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151220074410/http://www.tjsp.jus.br/Institucional/CanaisComunicacao/Noticias/Noticia.aspx?Id=29056 |date=20 December 2015 }}, Comunicação Social TJSP, São Paulo Court of Justice, 16 December 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.zdnet.com/brazil-passes-groundbreaking-internet-governance-bill-7000027740/ "Brazil passes groundbreaking Internet governance Bill"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025092023/http://www.zdnet.com/brazil-passes-groundbreaking-internet-governance-bill-7000027740/ |date=25 October 2014 }}, Angelica Mari, ZDNet, 26 March 2014.</ref><ref>[http://direitorio.fgv.br/noticia/the-brazilian-civil-rights-framework-for-the-internet "The Brazilian Civil Rights Framework for the Internet"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150514083732/http://direitorio.fgv.br/noticia/the-brazilian-civil-rights-framework-for-the-internet |date=14 May 2015 }}, Fundação Getulio Vargas (FGV), 9 May 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techtudo.com.br/noticias/noticia/2015/12/bloqueio-do-whatsapp-fere-o-marco-civil-da-internet-veja-posicao-do-cgi.html|title=Bloqueio do WhatsApp fere o Marco Civil da Internet? Veja a posição do CGI|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223011346/http://www.techtudo.com.br/noticias/noticia/2015/12/bloqueio-do-whatsapp-fere-o-marco-civil-da-internet-veja-posicao-do-cgi.html|archivedate=23 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politize.com.br/noticias/afinal-o-bloqueio-do-whatsapp-esta-de-acordo-com-o-marco-civil-da-internet/|title=Afinal, o bloqueio do Whatsapp está de acordo com o Marco Civil da Internet? - Politize!|date=17 December 2015|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416093422/http://www.politize.com.br/noticias/afinal-o-bloqueio-do-whatsapp-esta-de-acordo-com-o-marco-civil-da-internet/|archivedate=16 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Canada === {{main |Net neutrality in Canada}}
In a January 25, 2011 decision, the Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) ruled that usage-based billing could be introduced.<ref>[http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2011/2011-44.htm "Telecom Decision CRTC 2011-44"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316224937/http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2011/2011-44.htm |date=16 March 2015 }}, Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC), File number: 8661-C12-201015975, 25 January 2011.</ref> Prime Minister Harper signaled that the government may be looking into the ruling: "We're very concerned about CRTC's decision on usage-based billing and its impact on consumers. I've asked for a review of the decision."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/tech-news/pm-orders-review-of-internet-billing/article1890567/ |location=Toronto |work=The Globe and Mail |first1=Steven |last1=Chase |first2=Iain |last2=Marlow |title=Harper steps into Web dispute - The Globe and Mail |date=2011-02-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202070354/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/tech-news/pm-orders-review-of-internet-billing/article1890567/ |archivedate=2 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Some have suggested that the ruling adversely affects net neutrality, since it discriminates against media that is larger in size, such as audio and video.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pinto |first=Lindsey |title=What does Usage-Based Billing mean for Net Neutrality? |url=http://www.saveournet.ca/content/what-does-usage-based-billing-mean-net-neutrality |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101114061549/http://saveournet.ca/content/what-does-usage-based-billing-mean-net-neutrality |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 November 2010 |accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref>
In 2005, Canada's second-largest telecommunications company, [[Telus]], began blocking access to a server that hosted a website supporting a labor strike against the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hightechforum.org/fact-checking-net-neutrality-violations/|title=Fact-Checking Free Press Net Neutrality Violations - High Tech Forum|date=27 June 2017|website=hightechforum.org}}</ref>
===Chile=== {{Main|Net neutrality in Chile}} On 13 June 2010, the [[National Congress of Chile]] amended the country's telecommunications law in order to preserve network neutrality, becoming the first country in the world to do so.<ref>{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2011/jun/23/netherlands-enshrines-net-neutrality-law |title=Net neutrality enshrined in Dutch law |work=The Guardian |date=23 June 2011 |accessdate=23 June 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930112646/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2011/jun/23/netherlands-enshrines-net-neutrality-law |archivedate=30 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2010/08/27/navegante/1282907501.html |title=Chile publica su ley que garantiza la neutralidad de la Red | Navegante |work=El Mundo |location=Spain |accessdate=23 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110821192544/http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2010/08/27/navegante/1282907501.html |archivedate=21 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/sociedad/Quien/quiere/acabar/neutralidad/Red/elpepisoc/20100809elpepisoc_1/Tes |title=¿Quién quiere acabar con la neutralidad en la Red? |work=EL PAÍS |accessdate=14 September 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124134810/http://www.elpais.com/articulo/sociedad/Quien/quiere/acabar/neutralidad/Red/elpepisoc/20100809elpepisoc_1/Tes |archivedate=24 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This came after an intensive campaign on [[blog]]s, [[Twitter]], and other social networks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/sociedad/Quien/quiere/acabar/neutralidad/Red/elpepisoc/20100809elpepisoc_1/Tes|title=¿Quién quiere acabar con la neutralidad en la Red?|work=EL PAÍS|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> The law, published on 26 August 2010, added three articles to the General Law of Telecommunications, forbidding ISPs from arbitrarily blocking, interfering with, discriminating, hindering or restricting an Internet user's right to use, send, receive or offer any legal content, application, service or any other type of legal activity or use through the Internet. ISPs must offer Internet access in which content is not arbitrarily treated differently based on its source or ownership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idLey=20453|title=Law 20,453|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816104919/http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idLey=20453|archivedate=16 August 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== China === The [[China|People's Republic of China’s]] approach to internet policy does not account for Net Neutrality as the government uses ISPs to inspect and regulate the content that is available to their citizens. They typically block both foreign and domestic sites that the government wishes to censor in their country, using software and hardware that together are known as the "[[Great Firewall]]." Many of the sites that are on the Great Firewall’s blacklist are there because they provide information that the government cannot effectively alter permanently, such as large social media IPs or information sites such as Wikipedia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hu|first=Henry L.|date=2011|title=The Political Economy of Governing ISPs in China: Perspectives of Net Neutrality and Vertical Integration|jstor=41305255|journal=The China Quarterly|issue=207|pages=523–540}}</ref>
According to Thomas Lum, a specialist in Asian Affairs: "Since its founding in 1949, the People's Republic of China (PRC) has exerted great effort in manipulating the flow of information and prohibiting the dissemination of viewpoints that criticize the government or stray from the official Communist party view. The introduction of Internet technology in the mid-1990s presented a challenge to government control over news sources, and by extension, over public opinion. While the Internet has developed rapidly, broadened access to news, and facilitated mass communications in China, many forms of expression online, as in other mass media, are still significantly stifled. Empirical studies have found that China has one of the most sophisticated content-filtering Internet regimes in the world. The Chinese government employs increasingly sophisticated methods to limit content online, including a combination of legal regulation, surveillance, and punishment to promote self-censorship, as well as technical controls."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://italy.usembassy.gov/pdf/other/RL33167.pdf |format=PDF|title=Internet Development and Information Control in the People's Republic of China |accessdate=4 March 2009 |last=Lum |first=Thomas |date=10 February 2006 |work=CRS Report for Congress}}</ref>
===European Union=== {{main|Net neutrality in the European Union}} When the [[European Commission]] consulted on the EU's 2002 regulatory framework for electronic communications in November 2007, it examined the possible need for legislation to mandate network neutrality, countering the potential damage, if any, caused by non-neutral broadband access. The European Commission stated that prioritisation "is generally considered to be beneficial for the market so long as users have choice to access the transmission capabilities and the services they want" and "consequently, the current EU rules allow operators to offer different services to different customers groups, but not allow those who are in a dominant position to discriminate in an anti-competitive manner between customers in similar circumstances".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/information_society/policy/ecomm/doc/library/proposals/1472/comm_pdf_sec_2007_1472_1_en_documentdetravail.pdf.pdf|title=Impact Assessment on the proposals to amend the European regulatory framework (Working Document – SEC(2007) 1472) |accessdate=26 December 2008 |author=European Commission |authorlink=European Commission |date=13 November 2007 |format=PDF |page=91}}</ref> However, the European Commission highlighted that Europe's current legal framework cannot effectively prevent network operators from degrading their customers' services. Therefore, the European Commission proposed that it should be empowered to impose a minimum quality of services requirements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/information_society/policy/ecomm/doc/library/proposals/698/com_2007_0698_en.pdf|title=Article 22 of the proposed Universal Service Directive|work=Digital Agenda for Europe|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> In addition, an obligation of transparency was proposed to limit network operators' ability to set up restrictions on end-users' choice of lawful content and applications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/information_society/policy/ecomm/doc/library/proposals/698/com_2007_0698_en.pdf|title=Article 20(5) of the proposed Universal Service Directive|work=Digital Agenda for Europe|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
On 19 December 2009, the so-called "[[Telecoms Package]]" came into force and EU member states were required to implement the Directive by May 2011.<ref name="Eur-Lex.Europa.eu">{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:337:FULL:EN:PDF |title=Eur-Lex.Europa.eu |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="businessweek1">{{cite web|last=Meyer |first=David |url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/may2009/gb2009057_886976.htm?chan=top+news_top+news+index+-+temp_global+business |title=Europe Votes Sweeping Telecom Reform |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=7 May 2009 |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> According to the European Commission the new transparency requirements in the Telecoms Package would mean that "consumers will be informed—even before signing a contract—about the nature of the service to which they are subscribing, including traffic management techniques and their impact on service quality, as well as any other limitations (such as bandwidth caps or available connection speed)".<ref name="businessweek1"/> Regulation (EC) No 1211/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 established the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) and the Office<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:337:FULL:EN:PDF |title=Eur-Les.Europa.eu |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> [[Body of European Regulators of Electronic Communications]]. BEREC's main purpose is to promote cooperation between national regulatory authorities, ensuring a consistent application of the EU regulatory framework for electronic communications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2002:248:0001:0048:EN:PDF |title=Eur-Lex.Europa.eu |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
The European Parliament voted the EU Commission's September 2013 proposal on its first reading in April 2014 and the Council adopted a mandate to negotiate in March 2015. Following the adoption of the Digital Single Market Strategy by the Commission on 6 May, Heads of State and Government agreed on the need to strengthen the EU telecoms single market. After 18 months of negotiations, the European Parliament, Council and Commission reached two agreements on the end to roaming charges and on the first EU-wide rules on net neutrality on 30 June 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-15-5275_en.htm|title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - Roaming charges and open Internet: questions and answers|website=europa.eu}}</ref> to be completed by an overhaul of EU telecoms rules in 2016. Specifically, article 3 of EU Regulation 2015/2120<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:32015R2120&rid=2|title=Regulation (EU) 2015/2120 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2015 laying down measures concerning open internet access and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users’ rights relating to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile communications networks within the Union |accessdate=16 February 2016 |author=European Parliament and the Council of the European Union |date=25 November 2015 }}</ref> sets the basic framework for ensuring net neutrality across the entire [[European Union]]. However, the regulation's text has been criticized as offering loopholes that can undermine the regulation's effectiveness.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hern|first1=Alex|title=EU net neutrality laws fatally undermined by loopholes, critics say|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/oct/27/eu-net-neutrality-laws-fatally-undermined-by-loopholes-critics-say|accessdate=16 February 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=27 October 2015}}</ref> Some EU member states, such as [[Slovenia]] and the [[Netherlands]], have stronger net neutrality laws.
Article 3 of EU Regulation 2015/2120<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:32015R2120&rid=2|title=Regulation (EU) 2015/2120 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2015 laying down measures concerning open internet access and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users' rights relating to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile communications networks within the Union |accessdate=16 February 2016 |author=European Parliament and the Council of the European Union|date=25 November 2015 }}</ref> sets the basic framework for ensuring net neutrality across the entire [[European Union]]. However, the regulation's text has been criticized as offering loopholes that can undermine the regulation's effectiveness.<ref name=guardianeu>{{cite news|last1=Hern|first1=Alex|title=EU net neutrality laws fatally undermined by loopholes, critics say|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/oct/27/eu-net-neutrality-laws-fatally-undermined-by-loopholes-critics-say|accessdate=16 February 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=27 October 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213124554/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/oct/27/eu-net-neutrality-laws-fatally-undermined-by-loopholes-critics-say|archivedate=13 February 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Some EU member states, such as [[Slovenia]] and the [[Netherlands]], have stronger net neutrality laws. In Germany mobile device ISP's like Deutsche Telekom and Vodafone are offering services that might be seen as undermining net neutrality. The government agency overseeing the market (Bundesnetzagentur) stated, in general these plans are in alignment with net neutrality but forced the companies to adapt some changes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/1.5342660|title=Behörde verlangt: Telekom muss "Stream On"-Tarif verändern|date=15 December 2017|publisher=|via=www.faz.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/digital/netzneutralitaet-in-deutschland-auch-in-deutschland-ist-die-netzneutralitaet-durchloechert-1.3791748|title=Auch in Deutschland ist die Netzneutralität durchlöchert|first1=Mirjam|last1=Hauck|first2=Helmut|last2=Martin-Jung|date=17 December 2017|publisher=|via=Sueddeutsche.de}}</ref>
===France=== In France, on 12 April 2011, the Commission for economic affairs of the French parliament approved the report of MP Laure de La Raudière ([[Union pour un Mouvement Populaire|UMP]]). The report contains<ref>[http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/13/dossiers/neutralite_internet_reseaux.asp rapport de La Raudière] asseblee-nationale.fr, 27 August 2011</ref> 9 proposals. Propositions n°1 & 2 act on net neutrality.
===Indonesia=== Indihome, a subsidiary of Telkom Indonesia, is deliberately blocking Netflix and claimed that it is due to censorship and pornographic contents. On the other hand, it promotes Iflix, a Malaysian-based company that provides similar service as Netflix. Ironically the M-17 rated contents are also available on Iflix without further censorship from the provider.
===India=== {{Main|Net neutrality in India}}
On 8 February 2016, the [[Telecom Regulatory Authority of India]] (TRAI) banned differential pricing of data services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/telecom/trai-set-to-bar-differential-pricing-of-data-services-regulations-out-today/articleshow/50900423.cms|title=Trai set to bar differential pricing of data services, regulations out today|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821172404/http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/telecom/trai-set-to-bar-differential-pricing-of-data-services-regulations-out-today/articleshow/50900423.cms|archivedate=21 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = India blocks Zuckerberg's free net app - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-35522899|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-02-09|language = en-GB|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160209013308/http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-35522899|archivedate = 9 February 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref> As per TRAI's press release, the regulator had multiple responses soliciting different opinions with respect to its consultation paper. Considering all the responses, the regulator decided to have an ex ante regulation instead of a case by case tariff investigation regime. According to the TRAI this decision was reached in order to give the industry participants the much needed certainty and in view of the high costs of regulation in terms of time and resources that will be required for investigating each case of tariff discrimination. Ruling prohibits any service provider from offering or charging discriminatory tariffs for data services on the basis of content and also prohibits any agreement or contract which might have effect of discriminatory tariffs for data services or may assist the service provider in any manner to evade the regulation. It also specifies financial disincentives for contravention of regulation. However, the ruling does not prescribe a blanket ban on differential pricing and provides an exception in case of public emergency or for providing emergency services. Discriminatory tariffs are allowed in the case of an emergency. Lastly, according to TRAI this ruling should not be considered the end of the net neutrality debate. The regulator has promised to keep a close view on the developments in the market and may undertake a review after two years or at an earlier date, as it may deem fit.<ref>[http://www.trai.gov.in/WriteReadData/PressRealease/Document/Press_Release_No_13%20.pdf trai.gov.in] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208211507/http://www.trai.gov.in/WriteReadData/PressRealease/Document/Press_Release_No_13%20.pdf |date=8 February 2016 }}</ref>
In March 2015, the TRAI released a formal consultation paper on ''Regulatory Framework for Over-the-top (OTT)'' services, seeking comments from the public. The consultation paper was criticised for being one-sided and having confusing statements. It was condemned by various politicians and Internet users.<ref name=Politicos>{{cite news|last1=Singh|first1=Saurabh|title=Politicos slam TRAI's stance on net neutrality|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/technology/story/politicos-raise-concern-over-trais-threatening-consultation-on-net-neutrality/1/429135.html|accessdate=12 April 2015|work=[[India Today]]|date=8 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150412222226/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/technology/story/politicos-raise-concern-over-trais-threatening-consultation-on-net-neutrality/1/429135.html|archivedate=12 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gandhi|first1=Rajat|title=Net neutrality: Why Internet is in danger of being shackled |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-04-08/news/60943272_1_net-neutrality-telecom-operators-viber|accessdate=12 April 2015|work=[[The Economic Times]]|date=8 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=TRAIemails>{{cite news|title=Indians rally for Internet freedom, send over 1 lakh emails to TRAI for net neutrality|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/indians-rally-for-internet-freedom-send-over-1-lakh-emails-to-trai-for-net-neutrality/539553-11.html|accessdate=13 April 2015|work=[[IBNLive]]|date=13 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150415193045/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/indians-rally-for-internet-freedom-send-over-1-lakh-emails-to-trai-for-net-neutrality/539553-11.html|archivedate=15 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> By 24 April 2015, over a million emails had been sent to TRAI demanding net neutrality.<ref name=TRAIemails/><ref>{{cite web |title=India fights for #NetNeutrality |publisher=Cyber World Mirror |url=http://cyberworldmirror.com/india-fights-for-netneutrality/ |accessdate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503001041/http://cyberworldmirror.com/india-fights-for-netneutrality/ |archivedate=3 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Roy|first1=Prasanto|title=India's fight for net neutrality|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-32313704|publisher=BBC|accessdate=18 April 2015|location=India|date=18 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150420153507/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-32313704|archivedate=20 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Over 3 lakh emails sent to Trai in support of Net Neutrality, so far.|url=http://tech.firstpost.com/news-analysis/over-3-lakh-emails-sent-to-trai-in-support-of-net-neutrality-so-far-263021.html|publisher=FirstPort|accessdate=14 April 2015|date=14 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414210848/http://tech.firstpost.com/news-analysis/over-3-lakh-emails-sent-to-trai-in-support-of-net-neutrality-so-far-263021.html|archivedate=14 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The consultation period ended on January 7, 2016.
Ultimately, in the year 2018, the [[Government of India|Indian Government]] unanimously approved new regulations supporting net neutrality. The regulations are considered to be the "world's strongest" net neutrality rules, guaranteeing free and open internet for nearly half a billion people,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://money.cnn.com/2018/07/12/technology/india-net-neutrality-rules-telecom/index.html|title=India now has the 'world's strongest' net neutrality rules|last=Iyengar|first=Rishi|date=12 July 2018|website=CNN tech|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=31 August 2018}}</ref> and are expected to help the culture of [[Startup company|startups]] and innovation. The only exceptions to the rules are new and emerging services like [[autonomous driving]] and [[Telemedicine|tele-medicine]], which may require prioritised internet lanes and faster than normal speeds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/internet-to-remain-free-and-fair-in-india-govt-approves-net-neutrality/articleshow/64948838.cms|title=Web stays neutral for all as govt clears net neutrality|last=Doval|first=Pankaj|date=12 July 2018|work=The Times of India|access-date=31 August 2018}}</ref>
Violations of net neutrality have been common in India. Examples beyond Facebook's [[Internet.org]] include [[Aircel]]'s [[Wikipedia Zero]] along with Aircel's free access to Facebook and [[WhatsApp]], [[Bharti Airtel|Airtel]]'s free access to Google, and [[Reliance Communications|Reliance]]'s free access to Twitter.<ref name="NotJust">{{cite news|title=Not just Airtel Zero: Facebook to WhatsApp, everyone has violated Net Neutrality in India|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/social/net-neutrality-debate-its-not-just-limited-to-airtel-zero/|accessdate=4 May 2015|work=[[Indian Express]]|date=18 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504060356/http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/social/net-neutrality-debate-its-not-just-limited-to-airtel-zero/|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Net Neutrality: Whose internet is it anyway? |accessdate=20 April 2015 |author=Amrita Madhukalya |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-whose-internet-is-it-anyway-2078659 |work=[[DNA India]] |date=19 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419153307/http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-whose-internet-is-it-anyway-2078659 |archivedate=19 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Facebook's Free Basics program is seen by activists as a net neutrality violation, based on its provision of free-of-cost access to dozens of sites, in collaboration with telecom operators. There were protests online and on ground against the Free Basics program. The Free Software Movement of India also held a protest in [[Hyderabad]] and parts of [[Telangana]] and [[Andhra Pradesh]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tech/tech-news/Net-Neutrality-And-the-vigil-continues/articleshow/50493607.cms|title = Net Neutrality: And the vigil continues|date = 8 January 2016|work = |access-date = 9 January 2016|via = The Times of India|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160109082923/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tech/tech-news/Net-Neutrality-And-the-vigil-continues/articleshow/50493607.cms|archivedate = 9 January 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
===Israel=== In 2011, Israel's parliament passed a law requiring net neutrality in mobile broadband. These requirements were extended to wireline providers in an amendment to the law passed on February 10, 2014. The law contains an exception for reasonable network management, and is vague on a number of issues such as data caps, tiered pricing, paid prioritization and paid peering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://israeltechnologylaw.wordpress.com/2014/02/13/net-neutrality-ii/|title=Net Neutrality II|work=Israel Technology Law Blog|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
===Italy=== Since March 2009 in Italy, there is a bill called: ''Proposta di legge dei senatori Vincenzo VITA (PD) e Luigi Vimercati (PD)'' "Neutralità Delle Reti, Free Software E Societa' Dell'informazione".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://punto-informatico.it/2591643/PI/Interviste/ci-vuole-una-legge-rete.aspx |title=PI: Ci vuole una legge per la Rete |publisher=Punto-informatico.it |date=7 February 1996 |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> Senator Vimercati in an interview said that he wants "to do something for the network neutrality" and that he was inspired by Lawrence Lessig, Professor at the Stanford Law School. Vimercati said that the topic is very hard, but in the article 3 there is a reference to the concept of neutrality regard the contents. It is also a problem of transparency and for the mobile connections: we need the minimum bandwidth to guarantee the service. We need some principle to defend the consumers. It's important that the consumer has been informed if he could not access all the Internet. The bill refuses all the discrimination: related by the content, the service and the device. The bill is generally about Internet ("a statute for the Internet") and treat different topics like network neutrality, free software, giving an Internet access to everyone.
===Japan=== Net neutrality in the [[common carrier]] sense has been instantiated into law in many countries, including Japan. In Japan, the nation's largest phone company, [[Nippon Telegraph and Telephone]], operates a service called Flet's Square over their [[FTTH]] high speed Internet connections.
===Netherlands=== {{See also|Net neutrality in the Netherlands}}
In June 2011, the majority of the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Dutch lower house]] voted for new net neutrality laws which prohibits the blocking of Internet services, usage of [[deep packet inspection]] to track customer behaviour and otherwise filtering or manipulating network traffic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tweakers.net/nieuws/75223/tweede-kamer-neemt-telecomwet-met-netneutraliteit-en-cookieregels-aan.html |title=Tweede Kamer neemt Telecomwet met netneutraliteit en cookieregels aan |publisher=Tweakers.net |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> The legislation applies to any telecommunications provider and was formally ratified by the Dutch senate on 8 May 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/kst-24095-281.html |title=Frequentiebeleid; Motie; Motie Braakhuis c.s. over netneutraliteit |publisher=Zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2012/05/08/wet-netneutraliteit-aangenomen-door-eerste-kamer/ |title=Nieuwe Telecomwet aangenomen door Eerste Kamer |work=NRC Handelsblad |accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref>
===Portugal=== {{Expand section|date=June 2018}} As part of the European Union, Portugal is bound to the laws protecting net neutrality established by the EU in 2002. However, the Portuguese government still allows for certain kinds of pricing models which are banned under most net neutrality rules. They allow for broadband providers to offer special pricing packages in which customers can pay for extra data that is only designated for the use of specific websites. For example, one package allows customers to pay extra for more data that can be used for social media websites such as Facebook and Twitter. However, many supporters of net neutrality in Portugal have objected to this pricing model on the grounds that it creates another barrier to entry for all internet companies that are not included in the special data packages.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.euronews.com/2017/11/29/the-truth-about-portugal-s-net-neutrality-told-by-an-expert|title=The truth about Portugal's net neutrality, told by an expert|last=De Oliva|first=Ana|date=December 29, 2017|work=Euronews|access-date=March 5, 2018}}</ref> These kinds of pricing packages are not specifically addressed in the EU net neutrality rules, so they have been allowed to continue. However, on February 28, 2018, Anacom, the telecommunications regulatory agency in Portugal, accused the country's main broadband providers, MEO, NOS, and Vodafone, of violating the EU rules on net neutrality with their extra data packages. They granted the providers up to forty days to change their pricing packages.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/portugal-telecoms/portugal-telecoms-in-breach-of-net-neutrality-rules-regulator-says-idUKL8N1QI819|title=Portugal telecoms in breach of net neutrality rules, regulator says|last=Bugge|first=Axel|date=February 28, 2018|work=Reuters|access-date=March 5, 2018}}</ref> However, the law does not specify what sanctions are appropriate, leading to an unclear future in this ongoing battle.
On June 4, 2012, the Netherlands became the first country in Europe and the second in the world, after Chile, to enact a network neutrality law.<ref name=stb-2012-235>{{cite journal |title=''Wet van 10 mei 2012 tot wijziging van de Telecommunicatiewet ter implementatie van de herziene telecommunicatierichtlijnen'' |trans-title=Act of 10 May 2012 for the amendment of the Telecomminications Act for the implementation of the revised telecommunications directives |journal=Staatsblad van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden |date=4 June 2012 |volume=2012 |issue=235 |url=https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/stb-2012-235.html |accessdate=10 February 2014 |language=Dutch |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413181820/https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/stb-2012-235.html |archivedate=13 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=guardian20110623>[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2011/jun/23/netherlands-enshrines-net-neutrality-law "Net neutrality enshrined in Dutch law"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930112646/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2011/jun/23/netherlands-enshrines-net-neutrality-law |date=30 September 2013 }}. ''The Guardian'' (London). Associated Press. 23 June 2011. Retrieved 3 April 2014.</ref><ref name=eff20120521>{{cite web|title=The Netherlands Passes Net Neutrality Legislation|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2012/05/netherlands-passes-net-neutrality-legislation|publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation|accessdate=10 February 2014|date=21 May 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014150959/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2012/05/netherlands-passes-net-neutrality-legislation|archivedate=14 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The main provision of the law requires that "Providers of public electronic communication networks used to provide Internet access services as well as providers of Internet access services will not hinder or slow down services or applications on the Internet".<ref name=Telecommunicatiewet7.4a>{{cite web |title=wetten.nl - ''Wet- en regelgeving - Telecommunicatiewet - BWBR0009950'' |trans-title=wetten.nl - Laws and policies - Telecommunications Act - BWBR0009950 |url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0009950/Hoofdstuk7/Artikel74a/geldigheidsdatum_10-02-2014 |accessdate=10 February 2014 |language=Dutch |at=Article 7.4a |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315105419/http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0009950/Hoofdstuk7/Artikel74a/geldigheidsdatum_10-02-2014 |archivedate=15 March 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
European Union struck down roaming charges by creating a law in which companies cannot slow down services. There are exceptions to services being slowed down which include court order, security, or congestion on a website.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com.libezp.lib.lsu.edu/ehost/detail/detail?vid=9&sid=d5801546-48a2-40cf-b01e-a8a5c10b07d6%40sdc-v-sessmgr05&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZSZzY29wZT1zaXRl#AN=95535734&db=a9h|title=citation|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Because Portugal is a member of the European Union, it must follow all guidelines set by their Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communication (BEREC).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://berec.europa.eu/eng/document_register/subject_matter/berec/public_consultations/6259-contribution-by-portugal-telecom-to-the-public-consultation-on-berec-guidelines-on-the-implementation-by-national-regulators-of-european-net-neutrality-rules|title=Contribution by Portugal Telecom to the public consultation on BEREC Guidelines on the Implementation by National Regulators of European Net Neutrality Rules|website=berec.europa.eu|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref> Anacom reported that majority of the complaints it received in the first half of 2018 involving the communications sector were related to billing, service failure, and cancellation of service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.anacom.pt/render.jsp?contentId=1459913|title=Reclamações relativas ao sector das comunicações aumentaram 25% no 1.º semestre de 2018|last=ANACOM|website=www.anacom.pt|language=pt|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref>
===Russia=== After almost 4 years of discussion, in early 2016 [[Federal Antimonopoly Service]] approved a regulation blocking ISPs from throttling or otherwise blocking any websites apart from those blocked at the request of the [[Federal Service for Supervision of Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media]], thus protecting net neutrality in Russia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osp.ru/news/2016/0217/13031700|title=В России начали действовать принципы сетевой нейтральности {{!}} Все новости мира компьютеров и связи {{!}} OSP News {{!}} Издательство "Открытые системы"|website=www.osp.ru|language=en|access-date=2017-11-22|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201035418/https://www.osp.ru/news/2016/0217/13031700|archivedate=1 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.garant.ru/news/697085/|title=Определены основы управления интернет-трафиком|access-date=2017-11-22|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201033609/http://www.garant.ru/news/697085/|archivedate=1 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In September 2007, the Russian government's Resolution No 575 introduced regulation rules of telematics services. [[Internet service provider|Network operators]] (ISPs) could legally limit individual actions of the subscriber's network activity, if such actions threatened the normal functioning of the network. ISPs were obliged to exclude the possibility of access to information systems, network addresses, or uniform pointers which a subscriber informs the operator of communication in the form specified in the contract. The subscriber was obliged to take actions to protect the subscriber terminal from the impact of malicious software and to prevent the spread of [[spam (electronic)|spam]] and [[Malware|malicious software]] to its subscriber terminal. In reality, most Russian ISPs shaped the traffic of [[Peer-to-peer file sharing|P2P protocols]] (like [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]]) with lower priority (P2P was about of 80% of traffic there). Also, there was popular method, called retracker,<ref name="retracker">{{cite web | url= http://wiki.rutracker.org/Retracker.local |title=Local Retracker method of caching p2p traffic}}</ref><ref>[http://www.computer.org/portal/web/csdl/doi/10.1109/ICNS.2010.25 CARMA Based MST Approximation for Multicast Provision in P2P Networks] {{doi|10.1109/ICNS.2010.25}} quote:"Recently there have been some advances in the locality awareness for BitTorrent networks. Popular nationwide trackers (torrents.ru, for instance) have introduced so-called "retrackers"{{spaced ndash}}dedicated secondary servers. These servers are optionally connected to primary database but mainly supposed to only return peer list local to specific network scope."</ref> for redirecting some [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] traffic to the ISP's cache servers and other subscribers inside of a [[metropolitan area network]] (MAN). Access to MANs is usually with greater speed (2x–1000x or more, specified in the contract) and better quality than the rest of the Internet.
===Singapore=== {{main |Net neutrality in Singapore}} In 2014 and 2015, there were efforts to charge [[over-the-top content]] (OTT) providers (companies that provide [[streaming video]]). [[Infocomm Development Authority]] (IDA) has a Policy Framework for net neutrality that did not allow a surcharge. Consumers also argued that they already pay for their service and that they shouldn't have to pay more to access the sites they want to.
===Slovenia=== At the end of 2012, Slovenia legislated a law of electronic communication implementing a strong principle of net neutrality.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Uradni list Republike Slovenije|url = https://www.uradni-list.si/1/content?id=111442|website = www.uradni-list.si|accessdate = 2015-10-10|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151006163114/http://www.uradni-list.si/1/content?id=111442|archivedate = 6 October 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref> [[Slovenia]] thus became the second country in Europe to enact a net neutrality law. The Government Agency for Communications, Networks and Services (AKOS) is enforcing the law and executes inspections. In January 2015 it found [[zero-rating]] infringements at the two largest mobile network providers, Telekom Slovenije and Si.mobil (now A1),<ref>{{Cite web|title = AKOS: Telekom Slovenije in Simobil kršila nevtralnost interneta @ Slo-Tech|url = https://slo-tech.com/novice/t634024|website = slo-tech.com|access-date = 2016-01-14|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304035044/https://slo-tech.com/novice/t634024|archivedate = 4 March 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref> which were respectively "zero-rating the Deezer music service and the 'Hangar mapa' cloud storage service."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.technologyslegaledge.com/2015/01/net-neutrality-zero-rating-and-todays-news-from-the-netherlands-and-slovenia/|title=Net neutrality, zero-rating and today's news from the Netherlands and Slovenia|last=Conradi|first=Mike|date=January 29, 2015|website=DLA Piper|access-date=}}</ref> In response, AKOS banned zero rating for all services except three owned by the state incumbent.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} For this, AKOS was sued by Slovenia's telecom operators for violating their own net neutrality rules. A month later the agency found similar infringements at Amis<ref>{{Cite web|title = AKOS's decision no. 06101-1412/2014/4 of 20 February 2014|url = http://www.akos-rs.si/odlocba-06101-1412-2014-4|website = akos-rs.si|access-date = 2016-07-19|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160918014647/http://www.akos-rs.si/odlocba-06101-1412-2014-4|archivedate = 18 September 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref> (now Simobil) and Tušmobil<ref>{{Cite web|title = AKOS's decision no. 06101-1413/2014/4 of 20 February 2014|url = http://www.akos-rs.si/odlocba-06101-1413-2014-4|website = akos-rs.si|access-date = 2016-07-19|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160918010109/http://www.akos-rs.si/odlocba-06101-1413-2014-4|archivedate = 18 September 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref> (now Telemach). In July 2016 the Administrative Court of the Republic of Slovenia annulled the January 2015 AKOS decisions regarding price discrimination, stating that since it does not "restrict, delay or slow down Internet traffic at the level of individual services or applications" it does not violate net neutrality. The court also said that the Slovenian Electronic Communications Act "does not prohibit zero rating outright."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.technologyslegaledge.com/2017/07/zero-rating-and-net-neutrality-decisions-so-far-in-the-eu/|title=Zero-rating and net neutrality – decisions (so far) in the EU|last=Conradi|first=Mike|date=July 26, 2017|website=DLA Piper|access-date=}}</ref> This ruling was in accordance with the Competition Protection Agency (CPA), who felt that the "prohibition of zero-rated services may have been detrimental rather than beneficial for consumers."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/competition/publications/reports/kd0217687enn.pdf|title=Zero-rating practices in broadband markets|last=DotEcon Ltd|first=|date=February 2017|website=European Commission|access-date=}}</ref> Four months after the ruling of the Administrative Court, in November 2016, AKOS found Telekom Slovenije and Si.mobil in violation of net neutrality laws for discriminating against non-zero-rated traffic for customers who exceeded their monthly data limits.<ref name=":1" />
===Slovenia=== In Slovenia, with 1 January 2013 there is a new telecommunication law in effect which explicitly defines and requires net neutrality from telecommunication operators. Net neutrality is defined as a principle that every Internet traffic on a public communication network is dealt with equally, independent of content, applications, services, devices, source and destination of the communication.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wlan-si.net/en/blog/2013/06/16/net-neutrality-in-slovenia/|title=Wlan slovenija unofficial translation|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
===South Africa=== {{As of|2016}}, there is no law on net neutrality in South Africa. A White Paper was to be published by the South African government in March, 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pmg.org.za/committee-meeting/20996/|title=ICT Policy Review recommendations and implementation plan: briefing by Minister of Telecommunications and Postal Services & panel members {{!}} PMG|website=pmg.org.za|access-date=2016-06-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812055654/https://pmg.org.za/committee-meeting/20996/|archivedate=12 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> but it has not been published yet. However, the telecommunications regulator [[Independent Communications Authority of South Africa|ICASA]], and the [[Department of Telecommunications and Postal Services]] has been engaged in this debate. In March 2014, ICASA invited comments to its "Notice of Public Inquiry into the State of Competition in the Information and Communications Technology Sector",<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.icasa.org.za/Portals/0/Regulations/Working%2520Docmuents/NoticePublInqState%2520OfComp.pdf |title=Request Rejected |website=www.icasa.org.za |access-date=2016-06-17}}</ref> in which net neutrality was brought up, and comments were invited on the stakeholders' views on enforcement of net neutrality in South Africa.
Simultaneously, DTPS was in the process of providing an integrated [[Information and communications technology|ICT]] policy review, to provide recommendations on various issues of ICT policy in South Africa. They published a Green Paper and invited comments to the same. The Green Paper did not venture into the debate of net neutrality in detail and simply stated that it is an issue that must be taken into consideration. Following the Green Paper, a Discussion Paper was published in November, 2014, which also invited comments. Lastly, a [https://web.archive.org/web/20160927221802/http://www.dtps.gov.za/documents-publications/ict-policy-review/category/102-ict-policy-review-reports-2015.html Final Report] was published in June, 2015 by DTPS providing its policy recommendations. DTPS recommended that the broad tenets of net neutrality be adopted, with principles such as transparency, no blocking of lawful content, and no unreasonable discrimination in mind. They urged the government to set appropriate exceptions to the application of network neutrality principles, such as emergency services, blocking of unlawful content, etc.
===South Korea=== In South Korea, VoIP is blocked on high-speed FTTH networks except where the network operator is the service provider.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vonage-forum.com/ftopic15054.html |title=Service Blocked Korea |accessdate=26 December 2008 |last=Toth |first=Martin |date=30 June 2006 |work=Vonage VOIP forum}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In comparison to the United States, the debate concerning Net Neutrality is one that has not received much attention in the United Kingdom. The officials merely refer to such a concept as an open internet, as net neutrality is a term used originally in American politics. While it does seem to be a non-issue in the UK, there is indeed a defining characteristic in the neutrality debate there, as the arguments are often shaped by regulators. Also, these arguments are often influenced by the discourse of other countries in Europe, so much of the discussions that the UK has about open internet will be linked with those of other European countries listed on this page.<ref>Powell, Alison1, A.Powell@lse.ac.uk and Alissa2 Cooper. "Net Neutrality Discourses: Comparing Advocacy and Regulatory Arguments in the United States and the United Kingdom." ''Information Society'', vol. 27, no. 5, Oct-Dec2011, pp. 311-325. EBSCO''host'', doi:10.1080/01972243.2011.607034.</ref>
In 2007, [[Plusnet]] was using [[deep packet inspection]] to implement limits and differential charges for peer-to-peer, [[file transfer protocol]], and online game traffic.<ref>{{cite web |last=Anderson |first=Nate |url=https://arstechnica.com/hardware/news/2007/07/Deep-packet-inspection-meets-net-neutrality.ars/2 |title=Deep packet inspection meets 'Net neutrality, CALEA |website=Ars Technica |date=25 July 2007 |accessdate=23 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419235908/http://arstechnica.com/hardware/news/2007/07/Deep-packet-inspection-meets-net-neutrality.ars/2 |archivedate=19 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, [[Plusnet#Deep packet inspection and bandwidth management|their network management philosophy]] was made clear for each package they sold, and was consistent between different websites.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.plus.net/support/broadband/speed_guide/traffic_management.shtml|website= PlusNet|title= Broadband All about traffic management|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141129021315/http://www.plus.net/support/broadband/speed_guide/traffic_management.shtml|archivedate= 29 November 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
===United States=== {{Main |Net neutrality in the United States}} {{Long section|date=June 2018}} In 2005, under Republican Chair Abernathy, the FCC adopted policies and rules establishing principles of "network neutrality" in order to carry out the policy of the United States "to preserve the vibrant and competitive free market that presently exists for the Internet" and "to promote the continued development of the Internet," "encourag[ing] the deployment on a reasonable and timely basis of advanced telecommunications capability" – broadband – "to all Americans.".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-05-151A1.pdf|title=Appropriate Framework for Broadband Access to the Internet over Wireline Facilities|website=Federal Communications Commission|language=en|access-date=2018-02-23|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The FCC noted that Congress had cited the Internet's educational and informational importance, and the fact that "[t]he Internet also represents "a forum for a true diversity of political discourse, unique opportunities for cultural development, and myriad avenues for intellectual activity," as well as "play[ing] an important role in the economy, as an engine for productivity growth and cost savings."
One article on Net Neutrality detailed not only what it means for educators, but also described what would happen if it were to be taken away. The author, Chad Sansing, goes on to say that "...Without net neutrality, regardless of how much bandwidth any particular user has, Internet service providers can “throttle” the speed of delivery to privilege some bits of information over others, effectively slowing down some websites and services while speeding up others."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ezproxy.lib.usf.edu/login|title=USF NetID Single-SignOn {{!}} University of South Florida|last=Florida|first=University of South|website=ezproxy.lib.usf.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref>
In order "to ensure that providers of telecommunications for Internet access or Internet Protocol-enabled (IP-enabled) services are operated in a neutral manner," and noting that its "Enforcement Bureau recently entered into a consent decree to resolve an investigation with respect to the blocking of ports used for voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP)," the Commission adopted network neutrality principles "to preserve and promote the vibrant and open character of the Internet as the telecommunications marketplace enters the broadband age." The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals said, however, that because the FCC had previously said broadband Internet access services were not common carrier services, the common carrier network neutrality regulations exceeded the authority the FCC had imposed on itself. Therefore, in 2015, the FCC changed its analysis, reclassified retail providers of BIAS as common carriers, and adopted revised open Internet requirements.
Following the ruling in [[Verizon Communications Inc. v. FCC (2014)]], [[Net neutrality in the United States#Timeline of significant events|between July 15 and September 15]], the [[United States Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) received 3.7 million comments to change the Internet to a telecommunications service, which would allow the FCC to uphold net neutrality.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.publicknowledge.org/press-release/dc-circuit-affirms-fccs-open-internet-rules-protects-net-neutrality-for-c|title=D.C. Circuit Affirms FCC's Open Internet Rules, Protects Net Neutrality for Consumers - Public Knowledge|website=Public Knowledge|language=en|access-date=2017-02-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170416163533/https://www.publicknowledge.org/press-release/dc-circuit-affirms-fccs-open-internet-rules-protects-net-neutrality-for-c|archivedate=16 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 26 February 2015, the FCC ruled in favor of net neutrality by reclassifying broadband access as a telecommunications service, thus applying [[Common carrier#Telecommunications|common carrier]] protections under Title II of the [[Communications Act of 1934|Communications Act]] and section 706 of the [[Telecommunications Act of 1996|Telecommunications Act]] to [[Internet service providers]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=https://www.fcc.gov/general/open-internet |title=Open Internet {{!}} Federal Communications Commission |website=[[FCC|fcc.gov]] |accessdate=2016-08-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160828050332/https://www.fcc.gov/general/open-internet |archivedate=28 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }} accessdate=4 August 2016</ref><ref name="FCC-20150226">{{cite news |author=Staff |title=FCC Adopts Strong, Sustainable Rules To Protect The Open Internet |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0226/DOC-332260A1.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=26 February 2015 |work=[[Federal Communications Commission]] |accessdate=26 February 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226215816/http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0226/DOC-332260A1.pdf |archivedate=26 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="NYT-20150226">{{cite news |last1=Ruiz |first1=Rebecca R. |last2=Lohr |first2=Steve |title=In Net Neutrality Victory, F.C.C. Classifies Broadband Internet Service as a Public Utility |date=26 February 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/27/technology/net-neutrality-fcc-vote-internet-utility.html |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=26 February 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226212654/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/27/technology/net-neutrality-fcc-vote-internet-utility.html |archivedate=26 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 12 March 2015, the FCC released the specific details of its new net neutrality rule.<ref name="NYT-20150312b">{{cite news |last=Sommer |first=Jeff |title=What the Net Neutrality Rules Say |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/03/12/technology/net-neutrality-rules-explained.html |date=12 March 2015 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=13 March 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150313080607/http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/03/12/technology/net-neutrality-rules-explained.html |archivedate=13 March 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="FCC-20150315">{{cite web |author=FCC Staff |title=Federal Communications Commission - FCC 15-24 - In the Matter of Protecting and Promoting the Open Internet - GN Docket No. 14-28 - Report and Order on Remand, Declaratory Ruling, and Order |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0312/FCC-15-24A1.pdf |date=12 March 2015 |format=[[PDF]] |work=[[Federal Communications Commission]] |accessdate=13 March 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312200613/http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0312/FCC-15-24A1.pdf |archivedate=12 March 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> And on 13 April 2015, the FCC published the final rule on its new regulations.<ref name="CNET-20150413">{{cite web |last=Reisinger |first=Don |title=Net neutrality rules get published -- let the lawsuits begin |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/fccs-net-neutrality-rules-hit-federal-register-lawsuit-underway/ |date=13 April 2015 |work=[[CNET]] |accessdate=13 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414060656/http://www.cnet.com/news/fccs-net-neutrality-rules-hit-federal-register-lawsuit-underway/ |archivedate=14 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="FR-20150413">{{cite web |author=[[Federal Communications Commission]] |title=Protecting and Promoting the Open Internet - A Rule by the Federal Communications Commission on 04/13/2015 |url=https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2015/04/13/2015-07841/protecting-and-promoting-the-open-internet |date=13 April 2015 |work=[[Federal Register]] |accessdate=13 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150502021951/https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2015/04/13/2015-07841/protecting-and-promoting-the-open-internet |archivedate=2 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The rule took effect on June 12, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2015/06/12/net-neutrality-takes-effect-today-heres-how-it-affects-you/|title=Net neutrality takes effect today. Here's how it affects you.|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=23 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161102153411/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2015/06/12/net-neutrality-takes-effect-today-heres-how-it-affects-you/|archivedate=2 November 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2015, the [[United States Telecom Association]], which represents large [[telecommunications|telecom]] companies, filed a lawsuit against the FCC challenging the net neutrality rule.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/03/24/telecom-lawsuits-aim-to-kill-fcc-net-neutrality|title=Telecom Lawsuits Aim to Kill FCC Net Neutrality|website=US News & World Report|access-date=2016-05-24|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160621072741/http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/03/24/telecom-lawsuits-aim-to-kill-fcc-net-neutrality|archivedate=21 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Association argued that the FCC's classification of broadband carriers as "common carriers" was a form of administrative overreach.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/03/despite-fcc-net-neutrality-danger-ever/|title=A year after the FCC's order to treat ISPs like phone companies, net neutrality is still in danger|website=WIRED|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-24|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160528190401/http://www.wired.com/2016/03/despite-fcc-net-neutrality-danger-ever/|archivedate=28 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In June 2016, a divided panel of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit|Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia]] upheld the FCC's net neutrality rules and the FCC's determination that broadband access is a [[public utility]], rather than a luxury.
In January 2017, the [[Trump administration]] took office and [[Ajit Varadaraj Pai]] was appointed as FCC commissioner. On April 29, 2017, Pai released a proposal suggesting reclassification of broadband access as an information service and a decrease in legal regulations on Internet service providers.<ref name="NYT-20170429">{{cite news |author=The Editorial Board |title=F.C.C.
